name: Islamic Society of Central Jersey
mission: We aspire to be the anchor of a model community of practicing Muslims of diverse backgrounds, democratically governed, efficiently served, relating to one another with inclusiveness and tolerance, and interacting with the neighbors and the community at large in an Islamic exemplary fashion.‍The fundamental objective of the Society will be to seek Glory to Allah Subhanahu Wa Ta'ala. ‍The Quran, Sunnah and the Sharia shall always be the guiding light for the Society.
theoryOfChange: The Islamic Society of Central Jersey (ISCJ) partnered with Oaktree Institute for a year-long strategic planning journey from October 2024 through October 2025. This process aimed to clarify ISCJ's vision, align its leadership, and chart a sustainable roadmap for the future, focusing on turning strategy into real impact. During the implementation support phase, ISCJ finalized outcomes, Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), and a multi-year roadmap, with clear benchmarks to track progress.

evaluationSources: NJ Association of Independent Schools (NJAIS) candidacy

zakatClaimEvidence: The Islamic Society of Central Jersey (ISCJ) explicitly states on its website, 'The following application is used to apply for Zakat at Islamic Society of Central Jersey (ISCJ).' Additionally, 'Zakat' is listed as a donation category on their donation pages and payment portals. (Source: https://www.iscj.org/services/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

score_details.score_summary: Islamic Society of Central Jersey shows good impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

Additionally, 'Zakat' is listed as a donation category on their donation pages and payment portals. (Source: https://www.iscj.org/services/zakat)

all_citations.claim: The organization reports a program expense ratio of 32.2% and working capital of 101.2 months.
Total revenue for the organization is $2,240,124.
The mission of ISCJ is to provide social, religious, and cultural services to the Muslim community.
The organization has a established history of serving the regional community.
ISCJ provides various educational and religious programs such as Friday Halaqas.
The organization manages Zakat-ul-Mal collection and distribution and is Zakat-eligible.
The organization has successfully elected a female Chairperson.
Women have served in key leadership roles including Trustee and Overseer.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate score of 59/100, reflecting a balance between its robust financial reserves and a relatively low percentage of revenue spent directly on program services.
areas_for_improvement: program expense ratio of 32.2% indicates a significant portion of funds are allocated to administrative or other non-program costs
Transparency could be enhanced through more frequent third-party financial evaluations

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is rated at 32/50, representing a medium donor fit for those prioritizing religious and cultural causes [3]. The organization has a long-standing track record of community service and has shown progress in organizational diversity, including the election of female chairpersons and trustees [10][12].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates a moderate impact score of 33/50, focusing on capacity building within the community through its food pantry and Zakat distribution services [1][7]. While it maintains a total revenue of $2,240,124, its program expense ratio is 32.2%, suggesting that while the organization is financially stable with 101.2 months of working capital, direct program spending is lower than industry benchmarks [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Islamic Society of Central Jersey serves as a vital hub for religious, social, and cultural services for the regional Muslim community.
strengths: Maintains an exceptionally high level of working capital at 101.2 months
High fundraising efficiency with $0.00 spent per $1 raised
Strong history of female representation in leadership and governance roles
baseline_narrative.summary: The Islamic Society of Central Jersey (ISCJ) is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing comprehensive social and religious services to the Muslim community [3][4]. The organization manages critical community programs including Zakat-ul-Mal collection and distribution, a food pantry, and various educational initiatives [5][7].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate score of 59/100, reflecting a balance between its robust financial reserves and a relatively low percentage of revenue spent directly on program services.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization's <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 32.2%</cite> is critically low compared to the <cite id="1">Peer Program Ratio Median of 89.1%</cite>, indicating high administrative or non-program costs.
The organization has experienced a contraction in funding, with a <cite id="2">3-Year Revenue CAGR of -7.6%</cite>.

bbb_assessment.summary: BBB Wise Giving Alliance assessment is not available for this organization.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The low program expense ratio may be an artifact of how a religious institution categorizes facility maintenance and Imam salaries versus direct charitable programs.
risk_factors: <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 32.2%</cite> is critically low
<cite id="2">3-Year Revenue CAGR of -7.6%</cite> indicates declining revenue
case_against.summary: The primary concern for donors is the organization's financial efficiency regarding program spending. With a <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 32.2%</cite>, a significant majority of funds are not directly reaching community programs.

confidence.notes: Financial metrics are based on older tax filings, though governance data is well-documented.

known_gaps: Unclear breakdown of administrative vs program expenses

alignment.explanation: The alignment score (32/50) reflects a strong fit for local Muslim donors seeking to support religious and cultural infrastructure, with verified <cite id="7">Zakat-eligible programs</cite> serving the masakin (needy).
alignment.improvement: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors on the organization's website.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust ISCJ's long-standing community presence since it was <cite id="3">founded in 1970</cite> and its documented governance structures, including <cite id="9">21 active committees</cite>. However, the lack of a full Charity Navigator rating limits third-party verification.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should pursue full third-party evaluations and publish audited financial statements on its website.

impact.explanation: The impact score (33/50) is heavily constrained by the <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 32.2%</cite>, which is well below the <cite id="1">Peer Program Ratio Median of 89.1%</cite>. This is partially mitigated by a perfect <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>.
impact.improvement: The organization must significantly increase the proportion of its budget dedicated directly to program services to align with industry standards.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for local donors in Central Jersey who want to invest in long-term Islamic community infrastructure, religious education, and local social services.
donor_motivations: Want to support local religious and cultural institutions
Value organizations with strong female leadership representation
Prefer established institutions with deep community roots
giving_considerations: The organization has a critically low program expense ratio compared to peers
Revenue has been contracting in recent years
The charity holds massive financial reserves, meaning immediate survival is not dependent on new donations
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-efficiency international relief or those who require 80%+ of their donation to go directly to program expenses.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C indicates that while the organization tracks basic outputs and has a documented theory of change, it lacks rigorous third-party impact evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: ISCJ builds community resilience through a combination of religious services, educational academies, and direct social support like food pantries.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: For community centers, evidence often looks like sustained participation and leadership development rather than clinical outcomes.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With over 101.2 months of working capital reserves, the organization is highly financially secure and does not have an urgent funding gap for basic operations.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its long history (since <cite id="3">1970</cite>) and strong <cite id="8">female leadership representation</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains an exceptionally high level of working capital, with <cite id="1">101.2 months of working capital</cite> in reserve, ensuring long-term stability.
ISCJ operates with highly efficient fundraising mechanisms, spending exactly <cite id="1">$0.00 per $1 raised</cite>.
The organization has a strong history of female representation, with <cite id="8">23 women in leadership roles</cite> and <cite id="10">a female Chairperson elected</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: The Islamic Society of Central Jersey stands out for its robust institutional stability and inclusive community governance. Since being <cite id="3">founded in 1970</cite>, it has built substantial financial resilience, currently holding over <cite id="1">101.2 months of working capital</cite>. This reserve model ensures that community services, such as the <cite id="5">food pantry and educational programs</cite>, can continue uninterrupted during economic downturns. Furthermore, the organization's governance structure is notably inclusive for a religious institution, with <cite id="9">21 active committees</cite> and a documented history of <cite id="8">23 women in leadership roles</cite>, including the election of a <cite id="10">female Chairperson</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: The Islamic Society of Central Jersey (ISCJ) is a vital community institution that has been providing religious, social, and cultural services since it was <cite id="3">founded in 1970</cite>. Operating primarily in the USA, the organization manages a diverse portfolio of programs including <cite id="7">Zakat-ul-Mal collection and distribution</cite>, a food pantry, the Noor-Ul-Iman School, and a Quran Academy. Financially, the organization reported <cite id="2">Total Revenue of $2,240,124</cite> in its most recent available tax filing. While the charity demonstrates exceptional financial stability with over 101.2 months of working capital reserves, its <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 32.2%</cite> falls significantly below industry standards. However, the organization operates with remarkable <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, indicating that public donations are not consumed by fundraising overhead. The organization is <cite id="7">Zakat-eligible</cite> and has a documented history of inclusive governance, notably featuring <cite id="8">23 women in leadership roles</cite>.
